content.rendered:
PROUDLY PRESENTING

WINDEEE LIFT AND TURNTABLE

In 2011 The University of Western Ontario (UWO) was awarded a Canada Foundation for Innovation/Ontario Research Fund project to design construct, and operate the Wind Energy, Engineering, and Environment (WindEEE) Dome. Dymech Engineering was contracted to provide a lifting mechanism with top mounted integrated turntable assembly, and the associated control systems. The equipment is used to raise the test subjects and models into the test chamber and rotate them during testing.

This cut-away view shows the entire building including the test chamber. The round opening in the floor of the test chamber is the location of the platform at its raised position. To allow the researchers to build their models, and load test subjects onto the platform, the entire stage can be lowered to the basement level.

The side of the platform is a smooth surface of rolled aluminum. This surface allows for a seal to be made after the platform is raised into the test chamber. The closure is made by inflating a bladder seal that is installed along the perimeter of the opening.

The 5m diameter turntable was fabricated using hollow section aluminum extrusions and aluminum plate. It can rotate a full 360 degrees to a precision of 0.5 degree. This allows testing to be done with different orientations and wind attack angles.

To drive the rotation the turntable is equipped with 188 pins that engage with a UHMW drive gear to form a pinion and annular gear arrangement. A Servo motor in combination with a rotary absolute encoder was used to adjust the position of the turntable.

The control system for the lift and rotate functions, as well as health and safety management systems were also in Dymech’s scope of work. A local panel and control system components were provided to communicate with the facility DCS/PLC system. The controls could manually set the position of the platform and turntable, or allow remote control input from the facility main control panel. Safety lift-locks were installed on the lifting posts, and these locks were monitored to prevent operation and signal an unsafe condition when they are not engaged.

The maximum test subject weight is 2,500 kg w/ a non-concentric load of up to 454 kg. Wind speeds in the testing chamber are up to 150 km/h horizontally, 108 km/h vertically (downburst), and 170 km/h vortical flow. These wind loads add +/- 24,000N vertically and 600 Nm of torque to the platform.
